channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: How a Secretive Branch of ISIS Built a Global Network of Killers
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: A jailhouse interview with a German man who joined the Islamic State reveals the workings of a unit whose lieutenants are empowered to plan attacks around the world.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Israel Charges Palestinian Employee of Aid Group With Funneling Funds to Hamas
item.media:description: Mohammad El Halabi — an employee of World Vision, a Christian aid organization — at his indictment on Thursday on charges of funneling about $43 million in charity funds to Hamas.
item.description: Mohammad El Halabi, of World Vision’s Gaza branch, was said to have moved about $43 million over the past six years to the militant group’s military wing.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and DIAA HADID

item.title: Food Shortages and Sexual Assault for South Sudan’s Displaced
item.media:description: South Sudanese soldiers and displaced families at the Anglican church compound in Juba, the capital, last month.
item.description: Clashes between the country’s rival factions halted food distribution for tens of thousands of people in United Nations camps, and sexual violence has risen.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Boko Haram Leader Speaks on YouTube, Deepening Signs of Split
item.media:description: Abubakar Shekau in a video released by Boko Haram in 2014.
item.description: The audio recording of the leader, Abubakar Shekau, came hours after an Islamic State publication suggested that another militant had taken control of Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Government Forces Responsible for South Sudan Killings and Rapes, U.N. Official Says
item.media:description: South Sudanese women collected water in at a United Nations camp housing about 30,000 in Juba last month.
item.description: The United Nations human rights commissioner documented violence resulting from clashes between forces loyal to the president and to his rival, the vice president.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Brazil’s Other Olympic Spirits: Anger, Anxiety and Indifference
item.media:description: Demonstrators along the route of the Olympic torch relay in Rio de Janeiro protested on Wednesday against the spending of government money on the Olympics instead of education.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: With a president facing impeachment and a recession stunting the national economy, nearly two-thirds of Brazilians believe that hosting the Summer Games will have a negative effect on the country.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Abroad in America: Trying to Recognize America in a Wild Campaign
item.description: With less than 100 days until Election Day, a Times foreign correspondent sets out to explain the American presidential race to a global audience.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Turkey Issues a Warrant for Fethullah Gulen, Cleric Accused in Coup
item.media:description: A Turkish flag at Gundogdu Square in Izmir on Thursday during a rally to protest the failed coup attempt.
item.description: Mr. Gulen, who lives in a self-imposed exile in Pennsylvania, is accused of plotting the July 15 coup attempt that left more than 250 people dead.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Refugee? Jihadist? After Suicide Bombing, Germans Question Migrant Policy
item.media:description: After an explosion in Ansbach, Germany, the police guarded a house where a suicide bombing suspect had lived.
item.description: Mohammad Daleel, a 27-year-old Syrian, wounded 15 people with a backpack bomb. Now Germans wonder if they really know who is crossing their borders.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and BORYANA DZHAMBAZOVA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The i360, World’s Most ‘Slender’ Tower, Opens in England
item.media:description: The British Airways i360 observation tower in Brighton, England, on Tuesday.
item.description: As with many ambitious architectural projects, opinions of the futuristic 531-foot-high structure in Brighton are divided.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: In a Victory for Modi, India Overhauls Its Tangled Tax System
item.media:description: A vendor in New Delhi on Tuesday. Lawmakers reached a breakthrough Wednesday in a long battle over a constitutional amendment to introduce a single national tax.
item.description: The new measure, a victory for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will replace a thicket of state and federal levies with a single economic zone.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Bangladeshi Police Arrest 2 Suspected of Terror Attack on Bakery
item.media:description: Bangladeshi police officers at a checkpoint on a road leading to the Holey Artisan Bakery, the scene of a fatal attack and siege last month, in Dhaka, the capital.
item.description: Tahmid Khan, a student at the University of Toronto, and Hasnat Karim, a Briton working in Bangladesh, were said to have been hostages during the attack last month.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Australia Allows Abuse of Refugees to Deter Others, Rights Groups Say
item.description: Asylum seekers being held on Nauru are denied adequate medical care and exposed to crime, and depression and anxiety are rampant, a report said.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Scientific Evidence of Flood May Give Credence to Legend of China’s First Dynasty
item.media:description: A view of skeletons in a cave in a village called Lajia, which is said to have been destroyed in an earthquake in China thousands of years ago.
item.description: Historians have long wondered whether the Great Flood was a myth, but archaeologists and geologists have discovered data about a dam that supports the story.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: Trilobites: Finding Degas’s Lost Portrait With a Particle Accelerator
item.media:description: A portrait, seemingly of the model Emma Dobigny, that was painted over for another work by Edgar Degas. The image on the left was captured with conventional X-rays. The color reconstruction was made using data from X-ray fluorescence.
item.media:credit: Left: National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne, Felton Bequest, 1937; Right: David Thurrowgood.
item.description: Australian researchers have used X-ray fluorescence to reconstruct a hidden portrait under one of Degas’s paintings in stunning resolution.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Thailand Junta Seeks to Extend Its Power With Constitutional Referendum
item.media:description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, the prime minister and chief of the junta, in the southern Thai province of Narathiwat last month. The military government has blocked opponents from campaigning against a referendum on a new constitution.
item.description: The ruling generals have cast the national vote as essential to restoring democracy, but critics say the proposal would weaken the role of elected officials.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rome Journal: Roma Women’s Business Plan: Cook Their Way to a Better Life
item.media:description: Maria Miclescu, left, and Codruca Balteanu at a food stand run by the Gipsy Queens during a music festival in Rome in July.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Eager to build a future for their families outside Rome’s segregated camps, a group called the Gipsy Queens began a cooking business.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Australia Says It Will Devote More Resources to Climate Research
item.media:description: The Cape Grim research station on the island of Tasmania plays a unique role in measuring greenhouse gases because of its location.
item.description: The measures do not completely reverse deep cuts to the country’s science agency that drew protests from scientists, but they do appear to signal a turnaround.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)

item.title: Zhou Shifeng, Chinese Lawyer, Is Sentenced to 7 Years for Subversion
item.media:description: The lawyer Zhou Shifeng at his trial in Tianjin, China, on Thursday, in an image taken from video. His firm, Fengrui, represented dissidents like the artist Ai Weiwei and victims of a contaminated baby formula scandal in 2008.
item.description: Mr. Zhou was the focus of government ire as the leader of a law firm with nearly 100 employees, many of whom specialized in cases officials deemed sensitive.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Man Held After London Knife Attack That Killed an American
item.media:description: The police investigating the scene of a knife attack at Russell Square in London, near the British Museum.
item.description: The police said “mental health issues” appeared to have led to the attack in Russell Square, which also left five people wounded.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Straddling Bus, on a Test Run, Floats Above Streets
item.media:description: A prototype of the Transit Elevated Bus, which is 72 feet long and 26 feet wide, going for a test run in the Chinese seaside city of Qinhuangdao on Tuesday.
item.description: A colossal, street-straddling bus came a step closer to reality this week, when a prototype went for a trial run of a few hundred yards.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and EMILY FENG

item.title: Saudi Arabia Agrees to Help Stranded Workers, India Says
item.media:description: Towers under construction at the King Abdullah Financial District in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, in March. Some of the complex’s towers are being built by the Saudi Oger company and other construction companies.
item.description: Some Saudi companies, squeezed financially by a sharp decline in oil prices, have laid off thousands of foreign workers.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: The Interpreter: Donald Trump, Perhaps Unwittingly, Exposes Paradox of Nuclear Arms
item.media:description: A deactivated Titan II intercontinental ballistic missile in a silo at the Titan Missile Museum, a preserved military complex near Tucson.
item.description: Since the Cold War, leaders have grappled with the puzzling logic of weapons whose power comes in not being used.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Boko Haram May Have a New Leader, ISIS Magazine Suggests
item.media:description: A Nigerian soldier amid the ruins of a school in Borno State where Boko Haram kidnapped nearly 300 girls in April 2014.
item.description: An online magazine identified a key Boko Haram member, Abu Musab al-Barnawi, as the “governor” of West Africa, indicating a major promotion.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: A Coup, Terrorists and Inflation, Yet Investors Rush to Turkey
item.media:description: A rally against an attempted coup in Turkey last month. Turkey remains an attractive investment market, despite political and economic instability.
item.description: Desperate for yield, big investors are scooping up stocks and bonds in nations like Turkey and Brazil, ignoring political and economic perils.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: Pentagon Says Deso Dogg, Ex-Rapper and ISIS Recruiter, Survived Airstrike After All
item.media:description: Denis Cuspert, who the Pentagon said was killed in a U.S. airstrike in October, actually survived.
item.description: Defense officials had said that the former German rapper, who was born Denis Cuspert, was killed in an airstrike in October.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Einojuhani Rautavaara, Composer, Dies at 87; His Lush Music Found Wide Appeal
item.media:description: Einojuhani Rautavaara at his home in Helsinki in 2008.
item.description: Many called him the greatest Finnish composer since Sibelius. Esa-Pekka Salonen and Magnus Lindberg were among his students.
item.dc:creator: CORINNA da FONSECA-WOLLHEIM

item.title: Spain’s Political Parties Fail to Agree on Coalition Government
item.media:description: Mariano Rajoy of Spain, the acting prime minister, addressed a news conference after meeting with Albert Rivera, the leader of the Ciudadanos party, in Madrid on Wednesday.
item.description: Political deadlock going on seven months could force an unprecedented third round of national elections.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Pope Francis’ Remarks Disappoint Gay and Transgender Groups
item.media:description: Pope Francis in Krakow, Poland, in July. The pope spoke against what he called ideological colonialism.
item.description: Advocates reacted with dismay after the pope said that schoolchildren are being taught they can choose their gender.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: $400 Million Cash Payment to Iran Fuels Latest Campaign Dispute
item.media:description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, talking to the media during a daily briefing at the White House on Wednesday.
item.description: Donald Trump and other Republicans argued with the White House about what the payment was about: A cash ransom, failed foreign policy or opposition to a nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Montreuil Journal: Paris Partygoers, Bored and Short on Cash, Turn Suburbs Into Movable Fête
item.media:description: The Macki Music Festival at the Ourcq Canal outside Paris last week. Young and mostly middle-class Parisians have banded together to establish informal collectives to perform regularly at venues in suburbs.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The capital has seen much of its night life move to the socially and historically estranged suburbs as a new generation establishes an alternative to mainstream dance clubs.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: 33 U.S. Service Members Have Contracted Zika, Pentagon Says
item.description: Military officials said the disease had been found in men and women serving abroad, including a pregnant woman.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Plans Take Shape for François Pinault Museum in Paris
item.media:description: The Bourse de Commerce, center, in Paris.
item.description: The City Council has approved the project, which is to transform an 18th-century bourse into “The Pinault Collection, Bourse de Commerce.”
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Nepal Elects Pushpa Kamal Dahal as New Prime Minister
item.media:description: Pushpa Kamal Dahal, center, won the votes of 363 lawmakers in the 595-member legislature to become prime minister of Nepal on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Dahal, also known as Prachanda, brokered a coalition with a rival party to be prime minister on the condition that he pass the reins to that party in nine months.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: China Sentences Hu Shigen, Democracy Advocate, to 7 Years in Prison
item.media:description: Hu Shigen, in court in Tianjin, China, on Wednesday, has long been an outspoken advocate of religious freedom.
item.description: Mr. Hu, a fierce defender of the right to protest, has already served a 16-year term for helping publicize the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Hong Kong Restricts Election Candidates, Renewing Fears of Lost Rights
item.media:description: Edward Leung of the party Hong Kong Indigenous, leaving an election briefing for Legislative Council candidates in Hong Kong on Tuesday. He said he had been barred from running.
item.description: Election officers have blocked at least five candidates over questions about whether they acknowledge the city as an “unalienable part” of China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Sinosphere: China Reins In Communist Youth League, and Its Alumni’s Prospects
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping in Beijing last month. The Communist Party has announced a major reorganization of its Youth League, a training ground for many officials who have been marginalized under Mr. Xi.
item.description: The league has served as a cradle for generations of Chinese leaders, who rose through it into the high ranks of the party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: France’s President Says Trump’s ‘Excesses’ Make People ‘Want to Retch’
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France attending a Mass last week in Paris for a priest who was killed by attackers at a church in Normandy.
item.description: President François Hollande said a victory by the Republican nominee in the United States could herald a shift to conservative candidates in other countries.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Bitcoin Plunges After Hacking of Exchange in Hong Kong
item.media:description: A shop in Hong Kong that accepts the digital currency Bitcoin. Bitfinex, a Bitcoin exchange based in the city, said that any outstanding settlements would be made at the price before it reported the hacking.
item.description: Millions of dollars’ worth of the currency was taken from Bitfinex, causing a 20 percent decline in the price, which partially recovered later.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: HSBC Profit Down 40% in ‘Difficult’ Environment
item.media:description: HSBC’s reported on Wednesday that its profit fell 40 percent in the second quarter of this year amid uncertainty surrounding the outcome of the British vote in late June on leaving the European Union.
item.description: The bank warned that a “period of volatility and uncertainty” is likely to continue for some time after Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: What in the World: British Royal History, and Intrigue, in a Quaint German Town
item.media:description: The German town of Celle is an ancestral home of Britain’s royal family, the Windsors.
item.description: Celle, Germany, has played host to British royals on several occasions because of its role as an ancestral home of the House of Windsor.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: What in the World: A Mother’s Love? Of Course. Her Citizenship? Not So Fast.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Glyphstock/shutterstock
item.description: Laws in 27 countries say that only fathers, not mothers, confer their nationality on a child. If Dad is dead or missing, Baby may wind up stateless.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: What in the World: In France, a Recipe Squabble over Marseille Soap
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by neydtstock, nulinukas, nika novak, kai keisuke/shutterstock
item.description: Soapmakers want the government to protect their storied product from foreign imitations — if only they could agree on how to make the genuine article.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Sociopath’s Diary
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: “Truth is over. Attention spans are over — and I never had one anyway. That's what the press doesn't get.”
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: How Israel’s Modern-Orthodox Jews Came Out of the Closet
item.description: A rabbi thought he was taking a stand against advances in L.G.B.T. rights. But he proved only how open our minds have become.
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Editorial: Turkey’s New Anti-Americanism
item.description: In accusing the United States of aiding a coup attempt, the Turkish president has made tensions between the NATO allies worse.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
